docs.lead_paragraph: A couple with deep roots in the radical anti-abortion movement moved to Brooklyn two years ago and worked stealthily, until their arrest yesterday, to bring James Charles Kopp, the man accused of killing an Amherst, N.Y., doctor who performed abortions, to their apartment in East New York, according to a federal complaint. The complaint charges that Dennis John Malvasi, 51, one of the most violent abortion foes in the history of New York City, and his wife, Loretta Claire Marra, 37, who has often been arrested for chaining herself to abortion clinics, conspired to sneak Mr. Kopp into Brooklyn from France.

headline.main: Couple Accused in Plot to Sneak Fugitive to Brooklyn From France

docs.abstract: Brooklyn couple with deep roots in antiabortion movement are arrested on charge of conspiring to sneak fugitive James Charles Kopp from France to their apartmentin East New York; police seize Dennis John Malvasi, 57, one of most violent abortion foes in history of New York City, and his wife, Loretta Claire Marra, 37, who has often been arrested in antiabortion demonstrations; photos (L)

docs.lead_paragraph: NEW YORK SCHOOLS EVACUATED About 6,000 schoolchildren in Hastings-on-Hudson and Poughkeepsie were sent home yesterday after bomb threats were made in their districts. No explosives or suspicious packages were found. John J. Russell, the superintendent of the Hastings schools, said the police traced a threatening phone call that came into an elementary school. Lisa W. Foderaro (NYT) QUEENS: SANCTIONS OVER SURGERIES The New York State Health Department said yesterday that it would take action against a Queens home for the mentally ill, where some residents endured what the state called ''assembly line'' prostate surgery. The department said it would seek to revoke the license of the operator of the Leben Home for Adults, in Elmhurst, which remains open but cannot admit new residents. The operator, Jacob Rubin, has denied involvement in the surgeries and is expected to oppose the revocation. Clifford J. Levy (NYT)

docs.lead_paragraph: Economy Minister Domingo Cavallo won congressional passage of his emergency financial package today, which lent the shaky government some political relief and gave worried investors some hope that a crippling default can be averted. But Wall Street and political analysts say the Senate victory came up well short of a new lease on life for President Fernando de la Rúa, whose rumored resignation set local and neighboring stock and bond markets on a harrowing ride a week ago.

headline.main: Economy Aide To the Rescue, As Argentina Fights Default

docs.abstract: Argentina's economy minister, Domingo Cavallo, wins congressional passage of emergency financial package, lending shaky government some political relief and giving worried investors some hope that crippling default can be averted; political analysts do not expect new lease on life for Pres Fernando de la Rua, whose rumored resignation set local and neighboring stock and bond markets on harrowing ride (M)

headline.main: Transit Workers Rally Over Health Benefits

docs.abstract: Transit Transport Workers Union members rally in midtown Manhattan in dispute with MTA over its health benefits trust; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Transit Transport Workers Union members rally in midtown Manhattan in dispute with MTA over its health benefits trust; photo (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: The notice hangs on a drab wall in a remote clinic here, a symbol of this country's bold aspirations. It reads, ''AIDS treatment available here on request from the doctor.'' Every morning, as the mist swirls over the green hills and roosters serenade the sun, sickly men and women push through the battered door to see the miracle worker.

headline.main: AIDS Obstacles Overwhelm A Small South African Town

docs.abstract: Drug companies have slashed prices of lifesaving AIDS drugs, but even cheaper drugs are too costly for poor in public hospitals in South Africa, nation that is better off than most countries in Africa; officials say national health system, which was neglected under apartheid, is unprepared to distribute drugs and monitor compliance outside few big city hospitals, even if tablets were free; South Africa has 4.7 million people infected with HIV, more than any other country, and 600,000 of them need treatment; 40 percent of nation's clinics do not even offer HIV tests; doctors and health officials say recent price cuts in drugs will change nothing unless prices fall even more and donors come forward to help pay for drugs and health system improvements; situation in rural Hlabisa, South Africa, where one in three adults is HIV-infected, described; photos; map (M)
docs.snippet: The notice hangs on a drab wall in a remote clinic here, a symbol of this country's bold aspirations. It reads, ''AIDS treatment available here on request from the doctor.''    Every morning, as the mist swirls over the green hills and roosters...

docs.lead_paragraph: Admitting that they would miss the April 1 deadline for passing a budget, state lawmakers today passed emergency spending bills to keep the state government running for three more weeks. Budget talks between Gov. George E. Pataki and the leaders of the Senate and the Assembly have become deadlocked in recent days. The governor has accused the Legislature of proposing a ''spending binge'' and has insisted that state spending be kept to $83.6 billion, a 5.3 percent increase over last year. He argues it would be imprudent to raise spending further with the national economy skidding.

headline.main: Albany Remains Faithful to Its Traditions: The State Budget Will Be Late Yet Again

docs.abstract: New York State lawmakers, admitting that they would miss April 1 deadline for passing budget, pass emergency spending bills to keep state government running for three more weeks; budget talks between Gov George E Pataki and leaders of State Senate and Assembly have become deadlocked in recent days (M)
